Subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=C72HD4PCSmYUNfEkRk6WCe2VdbL7URm8LqdyVZRc6asa4612

alpanhell wrote:

> Am I missing something here?

Not really. setUp and tearDown are fundamentally weird, and way 
overemphasized in the JUnit tutorials. They're only a couple of corner 
cases where they matter. Specifically:

1. If you need to initialize static data before each test. Instance data 
can be initialized in the constructor because JUnit creates a new, clean 
object for each test.

2. If a test uses a lot of memory or some other scarce resource, and you 
need to explicitly free that resource in tearDown instead of waiting for 
garbage collection to do it.

As I said, these are corner cases. Most of the time you can happily 
write tests without using either of these methods.

--
